Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Evolution and Systematics of Claytonia lanceolata sensu lato (Montiaceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Polyploidization (whole genome duplication) is, and likely was, instrumental in the diversification of flowering plants. Understanding how and why polyploidy occurs in flowering plants may provide critical insight into the interplay of adaptation and historic environmental changes like glaciation, volcanism, and global climate change. This research will provide an improved understanding of diversification in the Claytonia lanceolata species complex, which is critical for effective conservation and management of the habitats in which they grow. Cutting edge biochemical and computational techniques now allow us to better estimate evolutionary histories, and test hypotheses concerning the ecological, temporal, and geographic context of speciation. This research will increase our understanding of gene dispersal via seeds and pollen, gene sharing among species, and the influence of chromosome number variation on plant diversification. A better understanding of relict alpine communities in California will be an additional, important contribution. Scientific communication, public outreach and mentoring undergraduate students are integral parts of the project as well.

Polyploidy, potentially giving rise to species complexes, represents one of the fundamental processes in diversification and polyploids are important elements of plant communities across the globe. Preliminary study indicates that the Claytonia lanceolata species complex (Montiaceae), as currently circumscribed, is non-monophyletic and consists of many polyploid lineages inhabiting a variety of unique spatial and ecological conditions in the mountains of western North America. This project involves research into biogeography, chromosome evolution, niche diversification, and phylogeny of the C. lanceolata species complex and close relatives. The project investigates (1) abiotic and biotic habitat characteristics in the field to better understand mechanisms responsible for reproductive isolation, (2) chromosome number within and among populations using flow cytometry and chromosome counting methods to characterize potentially adaptive variation, (3) variation in vegetative characters using morphometrics to better develop hypotheses concerning selection acting on leaf and subterranean stem anatomy and morphology, and (4) patterns of inter-specific gene flow in sympatric populations using Next Generation Sequencing (RADseq) to understand the extent to which species are reproductively isolated. This research will result in a significant revision of our knowledge of species boundaries and their distributions in the C. lanceolata complex, in addition to the description of several taxa new to science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tuberous perennial spring beauties, genus Claytonia L. (Montiaceae), grow in both North America and Eastern Asia. At least in North America, these captivating geophytes are exceptionally variable in terms of their chromosome numbers, ecologies, and morphologies; Claytonia lanceolata Pursh was considered among the most enigmatic of the North America perennial species by several early taxonomists. Overall diversity is not well understood in the genus, owing at least in part to the ubiquity of chromosomal variation, putatively stemming from repeated bouts of inter-species gene flow during past glaciation cycles, and the poor preservation of relatively succulent plant specimens. The genus recently underwent significant taxonomic review, resulting in a useful monograph that provides extremely helpful summary information about Claytonia nomenclature, but significant variation among other western North American species was lumped into the single taxon, C. lanceolata (with numerous synonyms).

In this study, a thorough review of C. lanceolata sensu lato was conducted, including extensive field, molecular, morphological, and ecological investigations, to bolster our understanding of species boundaries for enhanced taxonomic circumscription. Field work was primarily concentrated in California, Nevada, and Oregon, but additional field trips were made to nearly every state in the U.S. west of the Colorado River, as well as locations in the eastern U.S. and Canada. Molecular analyses included estimation of genetic differentiation and phylogenetic relatedness using traditional methods (Sanger sequencing) and multiple types of newer methods for obtaining DNA sequence data (Next Generation Sequencing). Morphometric analyses included the use of straight-line measurements obtained from plant specimens as well as geometric analyses of leaf shape outlines. Lastly, ecological analyses included soil chemistry assays to determine degrees of habitat differentiation among closely related species.

Results include the description of two new species, Claytonia panamintensis T.R. Stoughton and C. serpenticola T.R. Stoughton, accounting for only a small fraction of the lineage diversity in California. Claytonia lanceolata var. peirsonii (Munz and Johnston) is included in a new taxonomic combination for a primarily southern California species comprising four subspecies, three of which are new to science. Claytonia obovata Rydberg is the seventh taxon segregated from C. lanceolata in California, resurrected from a previous circumscription but with an enriched understanding of its morphology and evolutionary history. Patterns of variation based on morphological analyses appear to be more or less reflective of species relationships, with the exception of some geographically non-overlapping (and more distantly related) species sharing similar morphologies, especially in terms of leaf shape. Ecological analyses suggest that speciation has likely occurred in this group both in shared geographic space and in isolation, and that speciation in shared geographic space may have been facilitated by species-specific substrate preferences.

Information about inter- and intra-specific relationships, in combination with our understanding of the geologic history of western North America, is used in this study to reflect on how plant species and their geographic ranges change over time. Findings of this study are broadly applicable to biological problems concerning geographically wide-ranging complexes of closely related species, especially plants or other sessile organisms occurring on a vast array of substrates and exhibiting a broad spectrum of morphologies.
